rev.comment: These image usages do not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 39: Line 39:
=== Origins ===
=== Origins ===
â
[[Image:Mwom1.jpg|right|thumb|''The Mighty World of Marvel'' vol. 1, #1, Marvel UKâs first comic]]
+
In 1972, seeing a gap in the popular weekly comics market of the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Marvel Comics]] formed their own British publishing arm, Marvel UK (under the corporate name of '''Magazine Management London Ltd.'''). Though publishing comics in England for a British audience, Marvel UK was under the editorial direction of Marvel's New York offices, overseen by the young American writer/editor [[Tony Isabella]].<ref>Wymann, Adrian. [http://www.panelology.info/Marvel/Marvel-UK-1.html "The Mighty World of Bronze Age British Marvel (1972-1979) Part One, 1972â194: Setting Up Marvel UK,"] Panelology! (2009). Accessed June 5, 2011.</ref>
In 1972, seeing a gap in the popular weekly comics market of the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Marvel Comics]] formed their own British publishing arm, Marvel UK (under the corporate name of '''Magazine Management London Ltd.'''). Though publishing comics in England for a British audience, Marvel UK was under the editorial direction of Marvel's New York offices, overseen by the young American writer/editor [[Tony Isabella]].<ref>Wymann, Adrian. [http://www.panelology.info/Marvel/Marvel-UK-1.html "The Mighty World of Bronze Age British Marvel (1972-1979) Part One, 1972â194: Setting Up Marvel UK,"] Panelology! (2009). Accessed June 5, 2011.</ref>
Line 51: Line 51:
Marvel UK began to establish itself as a major publisher of weekly comic titles (along with [[D. C. Thomson & Co. Ltd|D.C Thomson]] and [[IPC Media|IPC]]) under the direction of editor-in-chief [[Neil Tennant]] (later one of the [[Pet Shop Boys]]). Tennant was responsible for [[Anglicisation|anglicising]] the dialogue of the comics to suit British readers, and for indicating where women needed to be redrawn more decently for the British editions.<ref>{{cite book | url= http://www.amazon.co.uk/Pet-Shop-Boys-Annually/dp/0723568421 | title= Pet Shop Boys, ''annually (1989)'' | year=1989}}</ref>
Marvel UK began to establish itself as a major publisher of weekly comic titles (along with [[D. C. Thomson & Co. Ltd|D.C Thomson]] and [[IPC Media|IPC]]) under the direction of editor-in-chief [[Neil Tennant]] (later one of the [[Pet Shop Boys]]). Tennant was responsible for [[Anglicisation|anglicising]] the dialogue of the comics to suit British readers, and for indicating where women needed to be redrawn more decently for the British editions.<ref>{{cite book | url= http://www.amazon.co.uk/Pet-Shop-Boys-Annually/dp/0723568421 | title= Pet Shop Boys, ''annually (1989)'' | year=1989}}</ref>
â
[[Image:SuperSpider-Man-CaptainBritan231.jpg|left|thumb|The cover of ''Super Spider-Man and Captain Britan'' #231.]]
+
However, with the exception of some new covers drawn by [[Marvel Comics]] American staff, no original material had yet been produced by Marvel UK. This changed in 1976 when ''[[Captain Britain]] Weekly'' was launched, featuring a hero created for the British market by [[Chris Claremont]] and [[Herb Trimpe]]. ''Captain Britain Weekly'' featured new stories in colour as well as reprints of ''[[Nick Fury]]'' and ''[[Fantastic Four]]'' strips as backup. It was initially a success but eventually combined with Marvel UK's [[Spider-Man Comics Weekly|''Spider-Man'' reprint title]] from #39.
However, with the exception of some new covers drawn by [[Marvel Comics]] American staff, no original material had yet been produced by Marvel UK. This changed in 1976 when ''[[Captain Britain]] Weekly'' was launched, featuring a hero created for the British market by [[Chris Claremont]] and [[Herb Trimpe]]. ''Captain Britain Weekly'' featured new stories in colour as well as reprints of ''[[Nick Fury]]'' and ''[[Fantastic Four]]'' strips as backup. It was initially a success but eventually combined with Marvel UK's [[Spider-Man Comics Weekly|''Spider-Man'' reprint title]] from #39.
Line 61: Line 61:
Skinn wrote: â[T]raditional British comics were at the time selling 150,000+ a week, firm sale, no returns. If Marvel and Spider-Man could look British enough for some of that to rub off, everybody would be happyâ¦But fixing the covers to resemble the non-glossy generic look of weekly anthology titles was one thingâ¦ Having âsplashâ pages and then five or six frames a page just didnât stack up against [[Warlord (DC Thomson)|Warlord]], [[Action (comics)|Action]], [[Battle Picture Weekly|Battle]] and the rest with their nine to 12 a page.â So the US artwork was re-sized to fit several pages onto one and emulate the look of the more established UK boysâ weeklies. <ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-2/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref>
Skinn wrote: â[T]raditional British comics were at the time selling 150,000+ a week, firm sale, no returns. If Marvel and Spider-Man could look British enough for some of that to rub off, everybody would be happyâ¦But fixing the covers to resemble the non-glossy generic look of weekly anthology titles was one thingâ¦ Having âsplashâ pages and then five or six frames a page just didnât stack up against [[Warlord (DC Thomson)|Warlord]], [[Action (comics)|Action]], [[Battle Picture Weekly|Battle]] and the rest with their nine to 12 a page.â So the US artwork was re-sized to fit several pages onto one and emulate the look of the more established UK boysâ weeklies. <ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-2/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref>
â
[[Image:HulkComic01.jpg|right|thumb|''Hulk Comic'' vol. 1, #1]]
+
Skinn reasoned that Marvel superhero weeklies had been effectively competing with each other in an already crowded market. So while the ''[[Spider-Man Comics Weekly|Spider-Man Comic]]'' was to be the flag ship superhero comic (with [[Thor]], [[Iron Man]], [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]], [[Fantastic Four]], and [[Nova]]), [[The Mighty World of Marvel]] was re-launched as ''Marvel Comic'', in the tradition of UK boysâ adventure titles. [[Dracula (comics)|Dracula]], [[Conan the Barbarian]], and [[Skull the Slayer]], joined (or re-joined) established strips [[Daredevil (Marvel Comics)|Daredevil]] and [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]]. Although the [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]] was replaced three issues after the re-launch by [[Godzilla (comics)|Godzilla]], as the Hulk left for his own title.<ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-2/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref>
Skinn reasoned that Marvel superhero weeklies had been effectively competing with each other in an already crowded market. So while the ''[[Spider-Man Comics Weekly|Spider-Man Comic]]'' was to be the flag ship superhero comic (with [[Thor]], [[Iron Man]], [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]], [[Fantastic Four]], and [[Nova]]), [[The Mighty World of Marvel]] was re-launched as ''Marvel Comic'', in the tradition of UK boysâ adventure titles. [[Dracula (comics)|Dracula]], [[Conan the Barbarian]], and [[Skull the Slayer]], joined (or re-joined) established strips [[Daredevil (Marvel Comics)|Daredevil]] and [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]]. Although the [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]] was replaced three issues after the re-launch by [[Godzilla (comics)|Godzilla]], as the Hulk left for his own title.<ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-2/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref>
The Hulk was a popular character â ''Rampage Weekly'' which starred [[The Defenders]] had been added to Marvel's list of publications under Tennant's editorship as a second vehicle for the green giant â and now with his own TV series Skinn saw the Hulk as the lead feature of another adventure style comic. ''[[Hulk Comic]]'' started out with originally produced Hulk stories created by [[Steve Dillon]], [[Paul Neary]], and [[John Stokes (artist)|John Stokes]] among others which reflected the green-skinned behemoth as depicted on the TV. Dez Skinn explained: âAs with Marvel Comic, I was wanting an adventure anthology title more than a super-hero one. Super-heroes had never been big sellers in the UK, we had plenty of legends of the past to spin fantasies about. So I went that route, picking existing Marvel characters who werenât really cut from the super-hero cloth.â <ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-3/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref> Originally produced stories were included, such as [[Nick Fury]], drawn by [[Steve Dillon]]; and [[Night Raven]] by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and [[David Lloyd (comic artist)|David Lloyd]]. Also included was the [[Black Knight (comics)|Black Knight]], a minor Marvel character but revamped to take in [[Arthurian]] concepts, as well as featuring the return of [[Captain Britain]] from comic book limbo. As well there was the usual US reprint material, such as [[Ant Man]] and in later issues the [[Beast (comics)|Beast]] from ''[[Amazing Adventures]]'' and even [[The Defenders]] were moved in from ââRampage Monthlyââ to increase the dose of Hulk action.
The Hulk was a popular character â ''Rampage Weekly'' which starred [[The Defenders]] had been added to Marvel's list of publications under Tennant's editorship as a second vehicle for the green giant â and now with his own TV series Skinn saw the Hulk as the lead feature of another adventure style comic. ''[[Hulk Comic]]'' started out with originally produced Hulk stories created by [[Steve Dillon]], [[Paul Neary]], and [[John Stokes (artist)|John Stokes]] among others which reflected the green-skinned behemoth as depicted on the TV. Dez Skinn explained: âAs with Marvel Comic, I was wanting an adventure anthology title more than a super-hero one. Super-heroes had never been big sellers in the UK, we had plenty of legends of the past to spin fantasies about. So I went that route, picking existing Marvel characters who werenât really cut from the super-hero cloth.â <ref>http://dezskinn.com/Marvel-UK-3/ DezSkinn.com . Accessed June 20, 2011.</ref> Originally produced stories were included, such as [[Nick Fury]], drawn by [[Steve Dillon]]; and [[Night Raven]] by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and [[David Lloyd (comic artist)|David Lloyd]]. Also included was the [[Black Knight (comics)|Black Knight]], a minor Marvel character but revamped to take in [[Arthurian]] concepts, as well as featuring the return of [[Captain Britain]] from comic book limbo. As well there was the usual US reprint material, such as [[Ant Man]] and in later issues the [[Beast (comics)|Beast]] from ''[[Amazing Adventures]]'' and even [[The Defenders]] were moved in from ââRampage Monthlyââ to increase the dose of Hulk action.
â
[[Image:Doctor Who Weekly 1.jpg|left|thumb|''Doctor Who Weekly'' # 1]]
+
Arguably Skinn's most important decision was to launch ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Weekly]]'' in 1979. Based on the [[BBC]] TV series (which at that point had already been running for 16 years), ''Doctor Who Weekly'' featured original comics stories by [[John Wagner]], [[Pat Mills]], and [[Dave Gibbons]], among many others, plus articles and features on the show itself. It proved a huge success and by now Skinn had transformed Marvel UK back to being a major publisher of not just weekly comics but monthly titles such as ''[[Starburst (magazine)|Starburst]]''. ''[[Starburst (magazine)|Starburst]]'' had been created by Skinn before he joined Marvel UK, but was purchased by Marvel when he joined the company.
Arguably Skinn's most important decision was to launch ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Weekly]]'' in 1979. Based on the [[BBC]] TV series (which at that point had already been running for 16 years), ''Doctor Who Weekly'' featured original comics stories by [[John Wagner]], [[Pat Mills]], and [[Dave Gibbons]], among many others, plus articles and features on the show itself. It proved a huge success and by now Skinn had transformed Marvel UK back to being a major publisher of not just weekly comics but monthly titles such as ''[[Starburst (magazine)|Starburst]]''. ''[[Starburst (magazine)|Starburst]]'' had been created by Skinn before he joined Marvel UK, but was purchased by Marvel when he joined the company.
Line 79: Line 79:
Classic Marvel material was by no means completely abandoned after the demise of the Pocket Books. The Hulk strips continued in a newly launched ''The Incredible Hulk Weekly'' and similarly the classic Fantastic Four strips resurfaced in a weekly title in October 1982. Both of these eventually folded into Spider-Man where the strips continued on and off until it changed into ''The Spider-Man Comic'' aimed at younger readers. The classic Spider-Man material continued in the first few issues of ''[[The Daredevils]]''.
Classic Marvel material was by no means completely abandoned after the demise of the Pocket Books. The Hulk strips continued in a newly launched ''The Incredible Hulk Weekly'' and similarly the classic Fantastic Four strips resurfaced in a weekly title in October 1982. Both of these eventually folded into Spider-Man where the strips continued on and off until it changed into ''The Spider-Man Comic'' aimed at younger readers. The classic Spider-Man material continued in the first few issues of ''[[The Daredevils]]''.
â
[[Image:Dd1.jpg|right|thumb|''The Daredevils'' vol. 1, #1]]
+
